key_points: Governor Mike Parson of Missouri has mobilized the Missouri National Guard to assist in Hurricane Ida recovery efforts in Louisiana.
Approximately 300 Soldiers from the Missouri National Guard will be deployed to aid in the relief efforts.
Governor Parson emphasizes the importance of states helping each other and the skills of the Missouri National Guard in recovery efforts.
The mobilization responds to a request from Louisiana through the Emergency Management Assistance Compact (EMAC).
The Missouri National Guard will provide humanitarian support, equipment, debris removal, and general support.
Soldiers from the 110th Maneuver Enhancement Brigade and the 35th Engineer Brigade are among those being mobilized.
Maj. Gen. Levon Cumpton, Missouri National Guard Adjutant General, highlighted the Guard's experience in recovery operations.
The deployment is set to last up to 14 days, with soldiers ready to assist as long as needed.
The effort is part of a mutual aid agreement among states for sharing resources during emergencies.
The initiative reflects a broader spirit of Americans helping Americans in times of crisis.
spokespersons: Maj. Gen. Levon Cumpton (Missouri National Guard Adjutant General)
